tossups.question: The earliest known image made by members of this religion is held at the Patna museum and is dated to approximately the 3rd century BC. One site in this religion is a building which models the terrestrial world as described in this religion’s cosmology, and is called Jambudweep. A prominent site of pilgrimage for this religion is a series of stone-carved temples at Mount Abu. One term in this religion translates to “illustrious or worthy person” and references (*) 63 people who will appear in every cycle. Practitioners of this religion often fast to death in a practice which is called sallekhana, which is not considered suicide. Sallekhana is considered a supplementary vow, taken in addition to the 5 main vows of this religion. For 10 points, identify this religion whose adherents practice ahimsa, or nonviolence, and was founded by Mahavira, .

One character in this play repeats the line “Besides, as far as Japan is concerned...” and references a man who “studied and studied and studied” to become a goldsmith. A character in this play gives a speech claiming that “A may often be B as well as A,” but “B may just as well be A.” Several characters in this play debate whether Large Dance Floor A is in fact larger than Small Dance Floor C. This play opens with its main character playing chess against himself. That character is sent to find a man who is off at a “committee meeting on the future of mankind,” named Mr. (*) Kalabis, and arrives at the title event, which is being held by the Liquidation Office. For 10 points, name this play in which Hugo Pludek learns to speak like a bureaucrat, the first play by Vaclav Havel.

During the Battle of San Pasqual, this man led reinforcements that had to sneak through the desert barefoot to avoid making noise. This husband of Making-Out-Road claimed that he never learned how to read as a child, because he was too busy fighting off Indian attacks. In one campaign, this man nearly drove a tribe to starvation by destroying its peach orchards in the (*) Canyon de Chelly. This former fur trapper was hired as a guide by a man who later campaigned on a partial slogan of “Free Soil and Free Men.” As a Union officer, this man oversaw the Long Walk, a forced migration of Navajo. He participated in the Bear Flag revolt alongside a companion known as “the Pathfinder.” For 10 points, name this mountain man who joined John Fremont on several expeditions, and is the namesake of the capital of Nevada.

A book by this thinker criticizes “new mysterians,” who claim there is a difference between the subjective and objective experiences of seeing the color red, instead arguing that consciousness is not a simple biological ensemble. This philosopher claimed that beliefs are real because they are based on patterns that independently exist in reality in his essay “Real Patterns.” This philosopher of (*) Bacteria to Bach and Back argued that, because qualia are a flawed concept, there is no hard problem of consciousness. In his most notable book, he categorized thought experiments like Searle’s Chinese Room Argument as “intuition pumps.” This thinker explained how powerful the idea is that humans evolved without a designer in Darwin’s Dangerous Idea. For 10 points, name this Tufts professor and philosopher, who wrote Consciousness Explained.

Michiel Kamp of Utrecht University is a member of an academic group dedicated to studying these works. One object that was very popular for creating early works of this type was the AY-3-8910. A website dedicated to these works was founded by djpretzel. They don’t have anything to do with films, but an essay on these works by Zach Whalen discusses the use of effects in them, known as “Mickey Mousing.” One series of performances of these works was created by Tommy Tallarico, and creators of these works include Yoko (*) Shimamura and Yasunori Mitsuda. High-quality rips of these works are very popular on YouTube. The first one of these works to win a Grammy was composed by Christopher Tin, and is a Swahili-language setting of the Lord’s Prayer, “Baba Yetu.” For 10 points, name these works that you may listen to while playing Super Mario Bros.
tossups.answer: video game soundtracks [or video game music; or video game OST’s] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: Wave normal surfaces are marked with the letters L, R, X, and O in a diagram representing phenomena in these systems. The frozen-in approximation simplifies analysis of these systems. The velocity of particles in these systems is usually assumed to be exactly orthogonal to the electric and magnetic fields, such that the current density term in Ohm’s Law is always zero. A ratio called (*) beta between the thermal and magnetic pressures must be kept low to prevent instabilities in these systems. Particles in these systems experience ambipolar diffusion when the Debye length is small, ensuring quasineutrality. The behaviour of these systems is described by magnetohydrodynamics. For 10 points, name these conductive systems of ionized gases, which constitute the fourth state of matter.

In this country, Daniel Axtell was court-martialed due to actions at Meelick Island. Casualties of a campaign in this country were recorded in the Down Survey. James Stafford’s treachery led to a massacre during a campaign in this country, where a cross in the town square was used to identify victims. Prisoners of war from this country who were shipped to the Caribbean are the progenitors of modern-day Redlegs. A plague outbreak in conjunction with a campaign in this country killed one of that campaign’s leaders, Henry Ireton. After that campaign, the first set of (*) Penal Laws was enacted to confiscate land from Catholics in this country. Brutal actions taken during a campaign in this country include the Sack of Wexford and the Siege of Drogheda. For 10 points, name this island that was subjugated by the Parliamentarians under Cromwell, resulting in the defeat of the Ulster Army.

This country’s second-largest city is centered around the Vauban-designed Petrovaradin Fortress. That city and its adjoining town of Srem were destroyed during the Revolutions of 1848. A “New” district of this country’s capital is located across the Sava River and contains the entertainment district of Filmski Grad. That city was founded around the Roman settlement of Singidunum. It’s not Ukraine, but one autonomous region of this country has six official languages, including Rusyn and (*) Aromanian. This country’s city of Raska was its ancient capital, and its city of Novi Sad is the capital of its autonomous region of Vojvodina. For 10 points, name this Eastern European country that claims Kosovo as its territory, and has its capital at Belgrade.

One of the few defendant-focused prerequisites for this procedural device was established in Supreme Tribe of Ben-Hur v. Cauble, and Exxon–Mobil v. Allapattah explained the intersection of this device with diversity jurisdiction. Lawsuits of this type have a reduced res judicata effect, per the Supreme Court’s decision in Hansberry v. Lee. In the United States, this litigation technique has increasingly resulted in “cy pres” awards to a third party. This type of lawsuit is easier to file since the passage of a namesake 2005 (*) “Fairness Act,” championed by supporters of tort reform. This procedural device is available when the plaintiffs demonstrate numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy. For 10 points, name this type of lawsuit, in which one or more plaintiffs represent a larger group.
tossups.answer: class action lawsuit [do not accept “collective action”, as per Black Law, that is when “Group's steps or actions while working toward a common goal.”] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: This author is the only female among the four authors who write in the “prophetic” mode, according to E.M. Forster’s Aspects of the Novel. Katherine Frank’s biography of this author diagnosed her with anorexia, while Claire Harman attributed this author’s difficult personality and love of the outdoors to Asperger syndrome. Some of this author’s poetry was rewritten after her death by an author who appears to her right in the “pillar portrait.” This author of “No Coward Soul is Mine” wrote a novel in which a man reflexively catches a falling baby despite hating its (*) alcoholic father, and later helps to raise the child. After that character created by this author starves himself to death, his ghost is spotted walking the moors with that of his love interest. For 10 points, name this author who created Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights.

Gallery owner Frank Lloyd became a fugitive from justice after tampering with evidence in a court case over this artist’s paintings. Some characteristics of this artist’s paintings have been attributed to him buying paint at Woolworth’s, although that story seems false. In 2015, Harvard’s Holyoke Centre premiered a digital projection system intended to let viewers see those works by this artist as they appeared before (*) fading. Philip Johnson designed a reflecting pool for a location containing this artist’s work, surrounding Barnett Newman’s sculpture Broken Obelisk. That building at the Menil Collection in Houston is this artist’s namesake chapel. This artist created a series of murals for a restaurant also designed by Philip Johnson, the Seagram Building’s Four Seasons. For 10 points, name this abstract expressionist known for his color field paintings.

He’s not British or American, but this man oversaw the arbitration that put an end to the Pig War. This future ruler was nicknamed “The Prince of Grapeshot” after he used artillery to crush an attempted uprising against his brother in 1848. This man’s government passed the Anti-Socialist laws after two assassination attempts on him late in his life. This man ruled the more northerly of the two countries that formed a Double (*) Alliance, which would later be joined by Italy. Unlike a subordinate he appointed Minister President, this man was generally opposed to anti-Catholic policies like the Falk Laws. He joined his general Helmuth von Moltke the Elder in commanding forces at the Battle of Sedan. For 10 points, name this ruler who delegated much power to Otto von Bismarck while serving as the first Emperor of a unified Germany.
tossups.answer: (Kaiser) Wilhelm I [or William I; prompt on just Wilhelm/William] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: This artist created a painting called The Peak Project depicting an unrealized project intended for the hills of Kowloon. A partner in this architect’s namesake firm coined the term parametricism to describe their work. This architect designed a Z-shaped secondary school in London called the Evelyn Grace Academy. This architect designed a building in Wolfsburg which rests on huge concrete stilts, allowing visitors to walk underneath it. This architect of the (*) Phaeno Science Centre also created a building with a wave-shaped roof which had spectator wings added for the 2012 Olympics, the London Aquatics Centre. This architect used floating stairs in a modern art museum in Rome called the Maxxi. For 10 points, name this postmodernist architect, a woman born in Baghdad.

For N particles, the grand canonical partition function equals the sum over N of the canonical partition function times a quantity with this name raised to the Nth power. Although this quantity normally does have units, in statistical mechanics, it names the exponential of chemical potential times beta. A dimensionless form of this quantity equals the exponential of the second virial coefficient times pressure over RT and is symbolized phi. For (*) gas phase reactions, the equilibrium constant is defined as the total product of this quantity for each species, raised to its stoichiometric coefficient. The extended formulation of Raoult’s Law just states that, at vapor-liquid equilibrium, this quantity is the same for the liquid and gas. This quantity is the pressure required for an ideal gas to have the same chemical potential as a real gas. For 10 points, name this quantity, from the Latin “to flee,” often described as the tendency of a substance to escape its phase.
tossups.answer: fugacity [or fugacity coefficient; prompt on f]

tossups.question: One empire based in this country had a prime minister who swore to become a vegetarian until its country was united under his rule. One king in this country, Iskandar Muda, was named for his status as a “second Alexander,” due to his conquests. One invasion targeting this country was led by an ethnically mixed triumvirate including Shi-Bi and Ike Mese, and was defeated in an ambush by Raden (*) Wijaya. Nine saints revered in this country for spreading Islam to it are known as the Wali Sanga. This country hosted the first conference of the Non-Aligned Movement, and it contains the cities of Surabaya and Yogyakarta. The Majapahit and Srivijaya Empires were headquartered in, for 10 points, what island country?

In his final letter, this author wrote that “the insane are always mere guests on earth, eternal strangers carrying around broken decalogues that they cannot read.” In a letter, this author advised his daughter that “all good writing is swimming under water and holding your breath.” This author fired off several nasty letters to an author who had satirized him as the painter David Knight in her only novel. This author listed putative titles for his best-known novel, such as The (*) High-bouncing Lover and Trimalchio, in a letter to his editor. That editor, Maxwell Perkins, advised him to give a character more distinctive traits along the lines of his catchphrase “old sport,” and praised the detail of the “expressionless” “great unblinking eyes of T.J. Eckleberg.” For 10 points, name this author who wrote many love letters to his wife Zelda and penned The Great Gatsby.
tossups.answer: F. Scott Fitzgerald [or Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald] <Ed. JO>

tossups.question: A solution to this equation in 3D can be written as the sum of two retarded layer potentials plus a volume potential, which can then be reduced to R squared using the method of descent. Kirchoff’s formula is used to obtain solutions to this equation. Characteristically, all solutions to this equation are unchanged by a shift of the form (*) “x plus ct” or “x minus ct.” Applying separation of variables to the spatial part of this equation yields the Helmholtz equation. The homogeneous form of this equation sets the second time derivative of some variable u equal to the velocity squared times the Laplacian of u. For 10 points, name this ubiquitous PDE, which describes the propagation of oscillations with crests and troughs.

A 2017 Nature paper by Erez et. al. shows this process is activated by the SAIRGA peptide and is coordinated between cells by the arbitrium system. This process is stimulated by the production of anti-Q RNA, which represses cro and activates the cI transcription factor. The “pseudo-” form of this process, upregulated when nutrients are scarce, forms an episome. Morons like gp35 and botulinum toxin are only expressed when this process is active in a symbiotic effect known as this process’ (*) “conversion.” Induction, the end of this process, is stimulated in lambda by activating the SOS response with UV light. This process results in a prophage when viral RNA integrates itself into the host genome. For 10 points, name this dormant phase of a viral life cycle, which alternates with the lytic phase.
tossups.answer: lysogeny [or lysogenic cycle; or other words forms; or formation of a prophage until it is read; prompt on bacteriophage genome integration]

tossups.question: In Schenkerian analysis, Phrygian [this number] is an alternative name for the Neapolitan sixth chord. In major, to colour the four chord before progressing to the dominant, you can only reasonably add the scale degree of this number. On the piano, playing the phrygian scale starting on D will have this many black notes. A chord that is notated V/V [v-slash-v] is rooted on the scale degree of this number. A major interval is this many semitones (*) higher than a diminished interval of the same numeric size. In the classical orchestra, there are generally this many of each woodwind instrument. This is the number of sharps in B minor and flats in G minor. The scale degree of this number, which is known as the supertonic, is the syllable “re” [ray] in solfege. For 10 points, how many staffs are usually used to notate piano music?
tossups.answer: two [prompt on supertonic, despite the tossup clearly saying “scale degree of this number”] <JS>

tossups.question: In an argument over the rulership of this country, one character describes himself as “the poisonous mushroom that makes the fearless vomit,” to which his enemy responds “I am the ravenous cock, the poison does not matter to me.” In that poem from this country, a jali named Balla composes the “song of the bow” to honour a man who bent a mighty iron rod into a curve. That character, the son of Maghann the Handsome, defeats an invader of this country by shooting him with an arrow tipped with a white (*) rooster’s spur. In an epic poem from this country, a king fulfils a prophecy by marrying a hunchbacked woman named Sogolon. That poem follows a prince who didn’t walk for many years, but united this country by defeating Sumanguru of Sosso. For 10 points, name this empire, whose formation is recounted in the oral Epic of Sundiata.

(TB) A disease that causes a compromised immune system and this other condition, Chediak-Higashi syndrome, can be detected through the presence of giant inclusion bodies in granulated cells. A misformed BLOC3 lysosome trafficking complex that causes this condition includes mutant proteins in the Hermansk Pudlak Syndrome family. The proximity of the (*) P protein with the chromosome 15q imprinting locus, explains its prevalence in Prader-Willi and Angelman syndrome. A deficiency in tyrosine 3-monooxygenase leads to this condition, which is most common in its oculocutaneous form, whose symptoms also include a lack of retinal pigment epithelium. For 10 points, name this condition, in which a lack of melanin results in unpigmented skin.

bonuses.leadin: This motif is a 60-residue helix-turn-helix found on the C-terminus of a POU domain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this protein motif that is highly conserved in Hox genes, such as the Antennapedia and Bithorax transcription factors in Drosophila.

Pax genes, which also contain homeodomains, regulate the development of these body parts in Drosophila. Thomas Hunt Morgan discovered that the color of this body part—usually either white or red—is sex-linked in flies.
In vertebrate eye patterning, Hox gene expression is regulated by this small molecule instead of proteins. This vitamin derivative promotes neural differentiation.

bonuses.leadin: The existence of the ability to create these things was revealed by Alexander Butterfield during testimony, thanks to a question from future Law and Order actor Fred Thompson. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Richard Nixon’s White house tapes [or the Watergate Tapes]
parts: Name these objects that contain an 18 ½ minute gap due to an error by Rose Mary Woods. They are currently held in a facility in Yorba Linda.
Nixon was forced to surrender the tapes after his claim of executive privilege was overturned in US v. Nixon That case was presided over by this Chief Justice, who also presided over Roe v. Wade.

Nixon had earlier offered to let this nearly deaf Senator listen to the tapes and summarize them for the Watergate special prosecutor. Archibald Cox’s refusal led directly to the Saturday Night Massacre.

bonuses.leadin: The bolometric form of this quantity is used to estimate it across all wavelengths, rather than just in the visible spectrum. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: magnitude [or apparent magnitude; or absolute magnitude]
parts: Name this dimensionless quantity, that corresponds to the luminosity of distant objects in astronomy. It can be measured as an apparent or absolute value.

The absolute magnitude can be calculated from the apparent magnitude by integrating over the “phase” type of this quantity, which is defined relative to the observer, the body, and the Sun. When this quantity is zero, an opposition spike results.
This quantity, symbolized mu, is defined to be the difference between the apparent and absolute magnitudes. When this quantity is zero, two objects are exactly ten parsecs apart.

bonuses.leadin: In W.G. Sebald’s novel Austerlitz, the narrator references the “murderous town of Bacharach,” in allusion to the death of Saint Werner of Oberwesel. For 10 points each,
answers_sanitized: to make matzo [prompt on making food, making bread, or making seder]
parts: Werner was supposedly killed by these people, resulting in an outbreak of violence against these people across Europe in 1287.
The conspiracy theory that Jews kill Christian children as part of their rituals is usually referred to by this term.
A stereotypical part of blood libel is the claim that Christian babies’ blood is collected and used in this way.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about translations of the Aeneid.
answers_sanitized: spelling Virgil’s name with an i instead of an e [accept anything that suggests “Virgil” instead of “Vergil.” The poplar-tree in Latin is called virga] <Ed. DS>
parts: The Earl of Surrey’s partial translation of the Aeneid is the earliest-attested usage of this type of poetry in English literature. This term typically refers to poetry written in unrhymed iambic pentameter.

A landmark English translation of the Aeneid, packed with such awful heroic couplets as “Two gates the silent house of Sleep adorn; / Of polish'd iv'ry this, that of transparent horn,” was made by this Restoration poet of “MacFlecknoe” and Absalom and Achitophel.

Sarah Ruden’s translation explicitly rejects this orthographic choice in the tradition of Virgil studies, which may acknowledge the legend that Virgil’s mother planted a poplar-tree to mark her son’s birthplace.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some painters who inspired poetry by Polish Nobel winner Wislawa Szymborska.
answers_sanitized: Pieter Bruegel the Elder [prompt on Bruegel] <DS>
parts: Szymborska’s poem titled for this artist states, in its entirety, “So long as that woman from the Rijksmuseum / in painted quiet and concentration / keeps pouring milk day after day / from the pitcher to the bowl / the World hasn't earned / the world's end.”

Szymborska’s poem titled for this artist describes a group of skinny sisters, who nobody saw “walking single file / onto the unpainted side of the canvas,” describing them as “exiles of style,” in contrast to the “Herculasses” and “fat love dishes” which typify “[this painter’s] Women.”

Szymborska’s poem titled for this artist describes a dream about an exam on the History of Mankind proctored by animals, a reference to this artist’s painting Two Monkeys. He also painted a bunch of animals in The Return of the Herd.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the economic history of the North Sea. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Sound Dues [accept Oresund Dues; or Oresundtolen]
parts: In his The Edge of the World, Michael Pye argues that modern capitalism was shaped by the North Sea trade in this fish that schooled regularly off the Scandinavian coast. This food product is used to make the Swedish dish suurstromming [Sir Stroaming].

For centuries, much of the Danish Crown’s revenues came from this toll, levied on ships passing through its namesake body of water from the North Sea to the Baltic Sea. Cannons placed at Helsingborg and Helsingor were placed to sink any ship that refused to pay it.

Although it was primarily based in the Baltic, this group of medieval seafaring towns headquartered at Lubeck also had outposts on the North Sea, such as those at Hamburg, Germany and Boston, England.

bonuses.leadin: How much do you know about weird stuff happening in lakes? For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: limnic eruption [prompt on outgassing, CO2 eruption, stuff involving a lake burping out lots of Carbon Dioxide]
parts: Only two instances of this have happened in recorded history, both in Cameroon in the 1980s. Thousands died after an occurrence of this type of natural disaster at Lake Nyos.
Lac Rose, so named because it’s pink due to Algal blooms, is located on this peninsula, also colorfully named, outside Dakar, the westernmost point in mainland Africa.
This lake in Israel is notably so saline you can’t sink in it. Its basin is the lowest point on Earth.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about “aleatoric” music, which incorporates random elements. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: 4’33” [“four thirty three;” or “four minutes, thirty three seconds”]
parts: This composer’s In C contains 53 different phrases, which generally must be played in order, but other aspects, such as speed, number of repetitions, or instrumentation can vary between performances.
This John Cage piece titled for a length of time is aleatoric, because the only sound comes from ambient noise that varies across performances.

Groups of orchestral sections repeat short passages until the conductor orders them to move on in the aleatoric piece Arc II: Textures by this composer of Toward the Sea and the viola concerto The String Around Autumn.

bonuses.leadin: A Balinese cup is used to represent these things in a common analogy of their key attribute: when they undergo a 360 degree rotation, their sign changes because the SU(2) group is not simply connected. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these mathematical entities, vectors modified to account for their namesake property.

Spinors were introduced by this British physicist to solve the equation which bears his name, which is a fully relativistic version of the Schrödinger equation. He also names a function which is infinite at the origin and zero elsewhere.

Conveniently, the Dirac spinors are easily written in terms of the basis states of this quantity’s operator, such that massless fermions have either a value of 1 or -1 for this value. If a fermion is massless, this quantity is a scaled version of the chirality.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the most important 2018 North American election: the Mexican general election. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Free and Sovereign State of Tabasco <HB>
parts: This current Mexican president cannot run for reelection due to the Mexican one term limit. This man may be lucky, though, as his approval rating was 12% in January 2017.

Currently, this leftist politician looks to be frontrunner to be the next Mexican president. He leads the MORENA party and is the former leader of the Party of the Democratic Revolution, with which he came in second place in 2006 and 2012.
López Obrador was born in this Southern Mexican state. This relatively poor state has had a recent oil boom and is home to a famous fair in Villahermosa.

bonuses.leadin: Critic Seth Simons’ review of this show’s fourth season was structured as a poem, beginning “I do not like the sad horse show.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Mitt Dermon; Bread Poot; Lernernerner DiCarpricorn; or Jurj Clooners [real names not acceptable] <Ed. JM>
parts: Name this animated Netflix show set in Hollywoo and centering on a depressive equine former sitcom star.
The voice of BoJack’s publisher Pinky Penguin is provided by Patton Oswalt. Oswalt’s only credited voice role in a film was as Remy, the protagonist of this Pixar film.

BoJack’s entirely post-production-added performance in Secretariat earns him a Best Actor nomination, but not a win. Give the first and last name of any one of the four actors who are also nominated against BoJack for the award. One of them eventually won for his performance in The Nazi who played Yahtzee.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about sources referenced in the titles of Aldous Huxley novels.
answers_sanitized: After Many a Summer Dies the Swan [the latter part is not necessary since it was published with a shortened title]
Le Meilleur des Mondes [accept anything that sounds like The Best of Worlds or The Best of All Worlds or The Best of All Possible Worlds] <DS>
parts: Huxley’s novel Eyeless in Gaza derives its title from this play by John Milton, whose title character has his eyes burned out by Philistines, but is nevertheless able to pull down the temple of Dagon.

This Huxley novel takes its title from a line in Tennyson’s poem “Tithonus.” In a stunning prediction of the life of Peter Thiel, it follows a Californian millionaire who pours his money into research on life extension.

You probably know that Brave New World derives its title from The Tempest. Interestingly, the French edition has this similar title, which it takes from a Dr. Pangloss quote in Candide. You may give an English translation.

bonuses.leadin: In a treatise on this philosophical field, Kant distinguished between four types of reflective judgement. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this subject of Kant’s Critique of Judgement, as well as his Observations on the Feeling of the Beautiful and Sublime.

This philosopher sought to formulate an institutional definition of art in The Transfiguration of the Commonplace. He also coined the term “artworld” and said a piece of art consists of its meaning and embodiment in the 2013 book What Art Is.

Danto wrote the introduction to the 1988 edition of this earlier American philosopher’s book about aesthetics, The Sense of Beauty. He said that beauty should be treated like a science because it is an objectified pleasure.

bonuses.leadin: The policeman who killed this protester was eventually revealed to be a Stasi agent. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Shah of Iran or Mohammed Reza Shah
Baader-Meinhof Gang [accept Red Army Faction; or Baader-Meinhof Komplex; or Rote Armee Faktion] <JM>
parts: Name this German university student, whose death sparked a wave of leftist protests. He had been demonstrating against a controversial state visit in front of the Berlin opera house.
That state visit was by this figure, the last ruler of the Pahlavi Dynasty. He led a country with its capital at Tehran.
Ohnesorg’s death played a key role in radicalizing this West German Communist terror group led by its two namesakes, along with Holger Meins and Gudrun Ensslin.

bonuses.leadin: While giving a speech to the American Sociological Association, this man defined the term “white-collar crime” as something the aristocrats did that was wrong. For 10 points each;
answers_sanitized: deviance [accept word forms such as deviant]
parts: Name this sociologist and author of Principles of Criminology. He also developed the theory of differential association, which purports to explain how some people become criminals.
Sutherland’s differential association theory attempts to explain actions of this type. Sociologists use this term for actions that violate norms or rules, such as laws.

Sutherland primarily worked at this Midwestern university. Its sociologists, like George Mead and Robert Park, formed a namesake School with theories of urban sociology, one of which was based on circles.

bonuses.leadin: One novel from this country tells the story of Tambu, who enters a missionary school after her brother dies. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country home to Tsitsi Dangarembga. Another novelist from this country, NoViolet Bulawayo, wrote about the adventures of a girl named Darling in We Need New Names.
In We Need New Names, Darling immigrates to this American city. Jeffrey Eugenides wrote about a family of Greek immigrants to this city in Middlesex.
This British author set her first novel The Grass is Singing in Zimbabwe, where she lived for a time. This first Nobel Prize winner to attend Comic-Con wrote The Golden Notebook.

bonuses.leadin: In high-temperature NMR of coordination complexes with this ligand, “ring whizzing” causes the carbons and hydrogens to coalesce into a single signal. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cyclopentadienyl ligand [or cyclopentadiene anion; or cp ligand]
parts: Name this aromatic, anionic ligand. Two of these ligands coordinate the iron atom in ferrocene.

Cyclopentadienyl anion is aromatic because it has this many pi electrons in the ring, the minimum number for a stable aromatic compound. Benzene has this many pi electrons, and this many carbon atoms.
Metallocenes with cyclopentadienyl are found in these catalysts which accelerate the polymerization of alkenes, though the most popular catalysts of this type are based on titanium.

bonuses.leadin: A contributing factor to this ruler’s unpopularity was the fact that a ton of his soldiers died of malaria during the conquest of Champa. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ruler, who was killed in a coup orchestrated by Yuwen Huaji. During his reign, components of a non-wall several century-old engineering project were all connected into one.

While Emperor Yang’s brutal rule led to the downfall of the Sui Dynasty, at least he could take credit for this previously-mentioned engineering project, a giant artificial river that still runs through Beijing in modern times.
Under Yang, China attempted to conquer this kingdom, which opposed Baekje and Silla during the Korean Three Kingdoms Period. That invasion failed after the Battle of the Salsu River.

bonuses.leadin: In this short story, a rabbinical student goes on a failed blind date with the schoolteacher Lily H. and gets annoyed when people call him “rabbi.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this short story about Leo Finkle, who enlists the marriage broker Pinye Salzman to find him a wife. He rejects Salzman’s suggestions before falling in love with a picture of Salzman’s daughter.

This author wrote “The Magic Barrel,” which appeared in a short story collection of the same name, along with “The Mourners.” He created Yakov Bov, who is accused of ritually murdering a Christian boy, in The Fixer.
Many of Malamud’s stories are set in the Jewish community of this city, where he lived. This Northeast city was home to a school of writers which included Frank O’Hara.
